title: Implementation Summary: Flexible Date Search
text: Users needed ability : 1. Search flights across flexible date ranges (e.g., “Dec 18 – Jan 5”) 2. Search across multiple airports/cities 3. Store scraped offers per date, extract cheapest 4. Output wide summary tables (City × Date Average Price) 5. Identify best travel dates automatically 6. Filter placeholder rows like “Price graph” 7. Support currency formatting 8. Include polite rate-limiting

title: Implementation Summary: Flexible Date Search
text: Note: implementation refactored based user feedback. See REFACTORING_SUMMARY.md details architectural changes. Four new exported functions added provide intuitive workflow:

title: Implementation Summary: Flexible Date Search
text: Purpose: Helper function create chain-trip Scrape object flexible parameters Parameters: - airports: Character vector 3-letter airport codes - dest: Character, single 3-letter destination code - date_min: Start date (Date character “YYYY-MM-DD”) - date_max: End date (Date character “YYYY-MM-DD”) Features: - Generates airport × date combinations - Creates chain-trip Scrape object WITHOUT scraping - Returns Scrape object ready pass ScrapeObjects() - Leverages existing chain-trip functionality Returns: Scrape object type “chain-trip”

title: Implementation Summary: Flexible Date Search
text: Purpose: Main scraping function multiple routes dates Parameters: - routes: Data frame columns City, Airport, Dest (+ optional Comment) - dates: Vector dates (Date objects character strings) - keep_offers: Logical, store offers cheapest (default: FALSE) - headless: Run browser headless mode (default: TRUE) - verbose: Show progress information (default: TRUE) Features: - Uses fa_create_date_range_scrape() create batch Scrape object - Calls ScrapeObjects() scrape queries one browser session - Filters placeholder rows automatically - Processes results user-friendly format - Comprehensive error messages Returns: Data frame columns: City, Airport, Dest, Date, Price, optionally Comment Offers

title: Implementation Summary: Flexible Date Search
text: Purpose: Create wide summary table easy comparison Parameters: - results: Data frame fa_scrape_best_oneway() - include_comment: Include comment column (default: TRUE) - currency_symbol: Symbol formatting (default: “$”) - round_prices: Round integers (default: TRUE) Features: - Reshapes data City × Date format - Calculates average price per route - Sorts date columns chronologically - Formats prices currency symbols (using scales package) - Handles missing values gracefully Returns: Wide data frame City, Airport, [Comment], date columns, Average_Price

title: Implementation Summary: Flexible Date Search
text: Purpose: Identify cheapest travel dates Parameters: - results: Data frame fa_scrape_best_oneway() - n: Number best dates return (default: 10) - : Aggregation method: “mean”, “median”, “min” (default: “mean”) Features: - Aggregates prices date - Supports multiple aggregation methods - Includes route count per date - Returns sorted results (cheapest first) Returns: Data frame Date, Price (aggregated), N_Routes columns

text: original implementation fa_scrape_best_oneway() handling browser initialization scraping internally: Issues: - Browser managed internally - Created many individual Scrape objects - Didn’t leverage existing chain-trip functionality - Duplicate scraping logic
code: fa_scrape_best_oneway(routes, dates, pause = 2, ...) {   # Initialize browser   browser <- initialize_chromote_browser()      # Loop through each route-date combination   for (combination in all_combinations) {     # Create individual Scrape object     scrape <- Scrape(origin, dest, date)     # Scrape immediately     scrape <- scrape_data_chromote(scrape, browser)     # Extract cheapest     results[[i]] <- cheapest_flight     # Rate limit     Sys.sleep(pause)   }      close_browser() }

title: Refactoring Summary: Flexible Date Search
text: Creates single chain-trip Scrape object permutations:
code: fa_create_date_range_scrape(airports, dest, date_min, date_max) {   # Generate all airport × date combinations   combinations <- expand.grid(airports, dates)      # Build chain-trip args: origin1, dest1, date1, origin2, dest2, date2, ...   args <- list()   for (combo in combinations) {     args <- c(args, list(combo$airport, dest, combo$date))   }      # Create single Scrape object   scrape <- do.call(Scrape, args)   return(scrape)  # No scraping yet! }

title: Refactoring Summary: Flexible Date Search
text: Now uses helper + existing ScrapeObjects():
code: fa_scrape_best_oneway(routes, dates, ...) {   # Create single Scrape object with ALL queries   scrape <- fa_create_date_range_scrape(     airports = routes$Airport,     dest = routes$Dest[1],     date_min = min(dates),     date_max = max(dates)   )      # Use existing ScrapeObjects() to scrape everything at once   scrape <- ScrapeObjects(scrape, verbose = verbose)      # Filter placeholder rows   scrape$data <- filter_placeholder_rows(scrape$data)      # Process into desired format   results <- process_scrape_results(scrape$data, routes, keep_offers)      return(results) }

title: Google Flight Analysis and Scraping
text: package now supports flexible date search across multiple airports dates, making easy find cheapest flights flexibility travel plans. Key Features: - Per-origin Scrape objects: origin gets chain-trip Scrape object (required due strict date ordering chain-trips) - Simple workflow: (1) Create list Scrape objects fa_create_date_range_scrape(), (2) Scrape ScrapeObjects(), (3) Pass directly analysis functions - Direct Scrape object support: fa_flex_table() fa_best_dates() accept lists Scrape objects directly - manual data processing needed! - Search multiple origin airports dates efficiently - Automatically leverages existing chain-trip functionality - Automatic filtering placeholder rows - Create wide summary tables easy price comparison - Identify cheapest travel dates automatically - Optional currency formatting scales package Single Origin Example:
code: library(flightanalysis) library(tibble)  # optional, for better data frame display  # Define routes to search routes <- tribble(   ~City,      ~Airport, ~Dest, ~Comment,   "Mumbai",   "BOM",    "JFK", "Original flight",   "Delhi",    "DEL",    "JFK", "",   "Varanasi", "VNS",    "JFK", "",   "Patna",    "PAT",    "JFK", "",   "Gaya",     "GAY",    "JFK", "" )  # Define date range   dates <- seq(as.Date("2025-12-18"), as.Date("2026-01-05"), by = "day")  # Step 1: Create Scrape objects for all routes and dates # Returns a list of Scrape objects (one per origin) for multiple origins scrapes <- fa_create_date_range_scrape(   origin = routes$Airport,  # c("BOM", "DEL", "VNS", "PAT", "GAY")   dest = "JFK",   date_min = min(dates),   date_max = max(dates) )  # Step 2: Scrape each origin for (origin_code in names(scrapes)) {   scrapes[[origin_code]] <- ScrapeObjects(scrapes[[origin_code]], verbose = TRUE) }  # Step 3: Analyze directly with list of Scrape objects # fa_flex_table and fa_best_dates now accept lists of Scrape objects directly!  # Create wide summary table (City × Date with Average Price) summary_table <- fa_flex_table(scrapes) print(summary_table)  # Find the top 10 cheapest dates best_dates <- fa_best_dates(scrapes, n = 10, by = "mean") print(best_dates) # For single origin, returns one Scrape object (not a list) scrape <- fa_create_date_range_scrape(   origin = "BOM",   dest = "JFK",   date_min = "2025-12-18",   date_max = "2026-01-05" )  # Scrape directly scrape <- ScrapeObjects(scrape, verbose = TRUE)  # Filter and analyze scrape$data <- filter_placeholder_rows(scrape$data) # ... apply custom filters or use fa_flex_table(), fa_best_dates()
